column1: ==== World War II and Japanese occupation ====
Naga came under Japanese occupation on December 18
column3: following the Japanese invasion of Legaspi a few days earlier.In 1945
column4: toward the end of World War II
column5: combined U.S. and Philippine Commonwealth troops—of the United States Army
column6: Philippine Commonwealth Army
column8: as well as Bicolano guerrilla resistance groups—liberated Naga from imperial Japanese troops.

column1: After Naga was liberated from the Japanese
column2: Naga began rebuilding. Having suffered only a few casualties
column3: Naga was able to rebuild quickly after the war. After many petitions
column4: Naga became a city on June 18
column6: when it acquired its present city charter; and its city government was inaugurated on December 15 of the same year by virtue of Republic Act No. 305.

column1: According to the Köppen climate classification system

column1: The weather in the city from March to May is hot and dry

column1: Naga is known for some native foods and delicacies.
Kinalas and lug-lug are noodle soup dishes served Bicol style
column2: similar to mami except for a topping of what looked like a pansit palabok sauce
column3: and the meaty dark soup made from boiling a cow's or a pig's head until the flesh falls off. Kinalas is from the old Bicol word kalas
column4: which refers to the "fall off the bone" meat that is placed on top of the noodles. The soup is the broth of beef bone and bone marrow (sometimes skull and brain included) or what Manileños call bulalo. The soup is topped with very tender meat slices that also came from the pig's head. It is usually served hot with an egg
column5: and sprinkled with roasted garlic and spring onions. Kalamansi and patis may be added according to taste. Kinalas is usually paired with Baduya
column6: or with Banana or camote cue.
